data.title: Lavish Palaces and Castles in Switzerland Keep Regal Secrets
data.meta_description: Unlock the magical history from a medieval past in stately palaces, opulent monasteries and storybook castles in Switzerland
data.text:
Unlock the magical history from a medieval past in stately palaces, opulent monasteries and storybook castles in Switzerland

Any group trip to Switzerland can be enhanced by taking a step back in time. And what better way to time-travel than visiting the ancient monasteries, stately palaces and impressive castles in Switzerland? They serve as an open book to this country’s rich heritage.

In Switzerland, there are dozens of captivating stories and treasures behind elegant castle gates, palace doors and monastery walls, all waiting to be discovered. And because Switzerland is about the size of Vermont, it’s easy to reach these historic places by car, train, bus or boat.

Celebrated Castles in Switzerland

Chillon Castle

Exquisite Chillon Castle, the most visited historic building in Switzerland, rests on the banks of Lake Geneva near Montreux. It sits majestically at the foot of the awe-inspiring Bernese Alps. For nearly four centuries, Chillon was the residence and toll station of the counts of Savoy. Today, visitors can tour the dungeon, medieval kitchen, halls and sleeping rooms. Additionally, visitors can see collections of ancient furniture and pewter. Even more, Lord Byron made the castle famous in his poem The Prisoner of Chillon.

Gruyères Castle

Gruyères Castle is a 13th-century landmark ensconced atop the quaint town of the same name. Accordingly, it offers grand vistas of Fribourg canton’s Alpine foothills. Treasures include stained-glass windows dating from the Middle Ages and capes belonging to Charles the Bold’s Knights of the Order of the Golden Fleece. Storytellers in medieval costumes recount the legends of the castle and region on entertaining guided walks. There’s also a multimedia show. The castle pairs well with a visit to nearby La Maison du Gruyère AOP, a show dairy where Gruyère cheese is made.

Hallwyl Castle

The 11th-century Hallwyl Castle is one of the foremost “water castles” in Switzerland. It is located at the northern end of Lake Hallwil on two islands near Seengen. The impressive complex, open to the public since 1925, was the family seat of the minor nobility of Hallwyl for 800 years. Members of this lineage made their mark on the battlefields of the old Swiss Confederacy, at the European courts, in science, politics, commerce and the world of finance.

Habsburg Castle

The 1020 Habsburg Castle, in the small town of Habsburg near the Aare River, is a medieval jewel. Hardly any other family has shaped European history as much as the Habsburgs. The remains of the front castle invite you to wander and climb. In addition, the majestic castle behind hosts a permanent exhibition on the dynasty’s colorful past. The most scenic way to approach the castle is to walk on winding forest trails from the town of Brugg.

Munot Castle

Munot Castle is a large, circular 16th-century Renaissance fortification crowning a round hill in the center of Schaffhausen. Surrounded by vineyards, the fortress serves as a symbol of this city on the Upper Rhine. The earliest presence of a castle dates to 1379, but the Munot was built between 1564 and 1589. Fallow deer were introduced to the fortress moat in 1905. In fact, they can still be viewed grazing happily undisturbed on the grass below the stone walls. In addition to the breathtaking scenery, the castle’s night watchman is exceptionally skilled at leading tours.

Bellinzona’s Trio of Castles

Castelgrande, the oldest of a trio of castles in Bellinzona, was built on a site first fortified in the 4th century. Easily identified by its two stone towers, the medieval monument stands on a flat-topped hill near the town center. It features two restaurants and a courtyard that’s perfect for picnics.

The second is the palatial Montebello Castle, built in the 14th century, expanded in the 15th century and renovated in the early 1900s. Due to it’s location, the castle affords sweeping panoramas of the city. Montebello is also home to the Civic Museum, which showcases archaeological artifacts from prehistoric burial sites in the region.

The third castle, Sasso Corbaro, dates from 1479 and houses exhibition halls and an excellent restaurant. The Sforzas built the geometrical structure after the defeat of Milanese troops at the Battle of Giornico; it was designed and completed in just six months.

Mystifying Monasteries

Old World monasteries throughout Switzerland have etched indelible marks on the nation’s history. Beyond their spiritual significance, these monastic beauties are cradles of art, literature and education.

Abby and Convent of St. Gall

It’s said that in St. Gallen you will find history at every turn, especially in its Abbey District. The spirit of the early Benedictine monks is discernible when you enter the famous Abbey Library, the world’s oldest library. It’s located at the Abbey and Convent of St. Gall, also known for its Baroque cathedral. In fact, the convent, including the library and monastery archives, was added to the UNESCO World Heritage list in 1983.

Monastery of Einsiedeln

Pilgrims have been visiting the extraordinary Monastery of Einsiedeln for more than 1,000 years. Founded by the Benedictine monk Meinrad in 835, the Baroque complex lies amid a breathtaking landscape with a deep blue lake and jagged mountaintops. In fact, it’s a major station on the Way of St. James. Another site is the black marble Mercy Chapel in the monastery church that contains the precious 15th-century Black Madonna.

Convent of St. John

The internationally-renowned Convent of St. John in Mustair contains the largest collection of early medieval frescoes from around the 800 period. The UNESCO World Cultural Heritage Site owes its existence to Charlemagne, being one of the few architectural examples from the Carolingian period. At the museum in the Planta Tower, visitors can view some of the convent’s inner workings. It also displays an exhibition presenting 1,200 years of monastic and architectural history. At the convent’s guesthouse and chapel, visitors may join in church prayers and the Eucharist. In addition, the smaller Holy Cross Chapel features Europe’s oldest dated wooden beam ceiling. Equally unique is that the area is bordered by the expansive Swiss National Park.

Disentis Monastery

Located southeast of Lucerne, Disentis Monastery is the spiritual and educational center of the Upper Rhine Valley. It’s also the oldest Benedictine abbey north of the Alps. Founded around 720, it has a museum with ecclesiastical art and exhibits on abbey history. Furthermore, Benedictine monks welcome visitors at their hourly prayers and at the celebration of the Eucharist.

Rapperswil Monastery

What’s special about Rapperswil Monastery at Rapperswil-Jona is that guests can truly immerse themselves in the life of the monastery community. Guests are asked to participate in the religious services and meditations during their time there. In fact, men and women of all denominations and religions are welcome. Firstly, guests are assigned an accompanying brother or sister. Additionally, the length of the stay is decided in advance, but always starts and ends on a Sunday. Rapperswil-Jona is located on the upper end of Lake Zurich. It combines Riviera-type sights, cultural life, hiking and sports possibilities with a Mediterranean holiday atmosphere.

Palatial Palaces

Chateau de Prangins

Chateau de Prangins was built in the 18th century with classic architecture by Louis Guiguer, a Swiss banker living in Paris. It has also hosted illustrious guests from Voltaire to Joseph Bonaparte. Overlooking Lake Geneva, the elegant building is home to one part of the Swiss National Museum. The chateau features a romantic French-style park and the largest historical vegetable and fruit garden in Switzerland. The permanent exhibition “Noblesse Oblige! Life at a Chateau in the Eighteenth Century” is set in the former reception rooms. These comprise the salon, dining rooms and libraries.

L’Isle Palace

L’Isle Palace is Versailles in miniature, a harmoniously designed palace in the French Neo-classical style. Located in the canton of Vaud in the Lake Geneva region, it was built in 1696 for French Army officer Charles de Chandieu. Purchased by the town in 1877 and now used as a school, it is not open to the public (except for banquets) and can only be admired from the outside.

Chateau de Villa

The exquisite Chateau de Villa, situated in the middle of rolling vineyards in Sierre, awaits your visit for a fine meal and delectable wines. In fact, raclette is a specialty of the house restaurant. In addition, the wine list features some 650 wines from more than 110 wineries in the canton of Valais.

Shadau Park Castle

Feed the ducks on the shores of Lake Thun or rest on a bench at Schadau Park Castle. The ornate edifice was built in the Romantic and Neo-Gothic styles between 1846 and 1854. Or you can take a walk along park paths through the woods and across inviting meadows. Catch great views of the Eiger, Mönch and Jungfrau peaks and then have brunch, lunch, tea or dinner in the castle restaurant. Afterward, stay the night in one of the luxurious rooms.

Stockalper Palace

In Brig-Glis, Stockalper Palace, built by Kaspar Stockalper in the 1600s, is an extension of his ancestors’ mansion. The massive palace is the largest Baroque secular building in Switzerland. In fact, it was nicknamed the “houses and the chapel of the Three Kings” by Stockalper, who was one of the most significant figures in the history of the canton of Valais. Stockalper was a statesman, politician, builder and jack-of-all-trades who amassed an impressive fortune. On the ground level, a museum features exhibitions on the history of the Simplon Pass and is the starting point for tours.

For more information, visit MySwitzerland.com/Castles.

More amazing Swiss adventures await in the current issue of our Switzerland Tour Guide, so download your copy today.

By Don Heimburger
